newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Mid-West power prices firm with cool weather.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Mid-West power prices firm with cool weather.

text.p: Spot wholesale electricity prices in the Midwestern U.S. were mostly higher Tuesday with below-normal temperatures and even snow boosting short-term heating demand, industry sources said.
Up to three inches of snow was reported in parts of Kansas and Missouri, and temperatures in Minnesota, North Dakota and Iowa were expected to reach highs in only the mid-40 degrees Fahrenheit today.
"It's frigid up here, and it's pushing prices higher," said one Mid-West marketer.

In the East Central Area Coordination Agreement (ECAR), peak, non-firm electricity prices for Wednesday delivery were said to be higher at $18.00-22.00 per megawatt hour (MWh) from $17.00-19.00 on Monday, the brokers and marketers said.
Off-peak next-day ECAR power was talked steady in the $12.50-14.00 area, the sources said.
November ECAR prices held at $17.25-17.55, while December was pegged steady near $18.70-19.10.
Peak, non-firm power prices for Wednesday delivery in the Mid-Continent Area Power Pool (MAPP) region were talked higher at $17.00-19.50 from $15.50-16.50 on Monday.
Off-peak non-firm MAPP power was also assessed higher at $9.50-11.50 from $8.00-10.00, the sources said.
In the Mid-American Interpool Network (MAIN), non-firm peak power for Wednesday delivery was said to also be stronger at $17.00-19.50 from $16.50-19.00 for Tuesday delivery.
Off-peak next day MAIN power was pegged steady in the $11.50-13.00 range.
In the Southwest Power Pool (SPP), peak, non-firm power for Wednesday delivery was assessed steady at strong prices of $21.00-25.00, the sources said.
Off-peak prices in SPP held steady in the $12.00-14.00 area, the sources said.
December SPP was discussed higher at $20.50-20.75 from the $20.25-20.50 range on Monday, the sources said.
Temperatures were forecast to remain at or below normal through most of the U.S., with the exception of some above-normal temperatures in the Northeast, through to the end of October.
-- Chris Reese, New York Power Desk 212-859-1627
